page.title: 03Selsdon nature reserve
page.content: Selsdon nature reserve started in 1924 when the Surrey garden village trust gave five acres to a scheme to preserve sixteen arces of Courtwood. Great support had been given to this scheme and a committee was formed to raise money to buy neighbouring pieces of woodland.The plants of Selsdon wood are lovely in spring.The spring wood is a sheet of bluebells and a world of honey suckle, wild roses and in the tangle of the grass deadly night shade grows waist high.Three areas of the woodland have been fenced off as special bird sanctuaries to encourage the shyer birds.More than 70 species of birds have been spotted in Selsdon wood, including tree creeper, long tailed tit willow, great spotted wood pecker and the house martin.
